qas.question: What was Northwestern's founding purpose in 1851?
When did instruction begin at Northwestern?
When were women first admitted to Northwestern?
How many acres is the modern-day Northwestern campus in Evanston?
What programs are offered at Northwestern's Quatar campus?
Which great lake is Northwestern located along?
What is the name of the city located 12 miles north of Northwestern?
In what year did Northwestern University stop teaching?
Where did Northwestern University opened an additional campus at in 2007?
What year were men allowed to attend Northwestern University?

context: Northwestern was founded in <b8_0>1851<b8_0/> by <b7_0>John Evans<b7_0/>, for whom the City of Evanston is named, and eight other lawyers, businessmen and Methodist leaders. Its founding purpose was <a0_0>to serve the Northwest Territory<a0_0/>, an area that today includes the states of Ohio, Indiana, Illinois, Michigan, Wisconsin and parts of Minnesota. Instruction began in <a1_0><b9_0>1855<b9_0/><a1_0/>; women were admitted in <a2_0><b11_0>1869<b11_0/><a2_0/>. Today, the main campus is a <a3_0>240<a3_0/>-acre (97 ha) parcel in Evanston, along the shores of <a5_0>Lake Michigan<a5_0/> just 12 miles north of downtown <a6_0>Chicago<a6_0/>. The university's law, medical, and professional schools are located on a 25-acre (10 ha) campus in Chicago's Streeterville neighborhood. In 2008, the university opened a campus in <b10_0>Education City, Doha, Qatar<b10_0/> with programs in <a4_0>journalism and communication<a4_0/>.
